channel.title: @hyperdbg - Telegram group archive
channel.description: Public archive of HyperDbg Telegram messages.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-17 17:01:03+00:00 (#9714)
item.description: https://rayanfam.com/topics/hypervisor-from-scratch-part-8/#whats-a-spinlock

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-17 17:00:28+00:00 (#9713)
item.description: So, it's like you put a spinlock and lock it, another thread (or core) also needs to lock the spinlock and because it's already locked, the new thread couldn't lock it and it prevent the modification by two (or more) threads or cores.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-17 16:59:11+00:00 (#9712)
item.description: Here is a very basic example of using a spinlock in a C code. The same concept applies to HyperDbg's script engine spinlock function (you need to use it like this.).

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-05-17 16:54:54+00:00 (#9711)
item.description: And since physical address space is sort of huge, you can save some memory for EPT tables using large or even huge EPT

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-17 16:54:29+00:00 (#9710)
item.description: This is the entire MTRR logic of HyperDbg: https://github.com/HyperDbg/HyperDbg/blob/6a1da349effc8879770eadd14e928964d1257d81/hyperdbg/hyperhv/code/vmm/ept/Ept.c#L156

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-17 16:54:01+00:00 (#9709)
item.description: Yes, you're right.

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-05-17 16:53:54+00:00 (#9708)
item.description: The only thing that limits it is a width of a physical address

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-05-17 16:53:37+00:00 (#9707)
item.description: You can point your MMIO BAR to almost anywhere on the physical address space. If there is no dram, it will just go to DMI decode

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-05-17 16:52:46+00:00 (#9706)
item.description: Something something DEF MSR, don’t remember the name now

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-05-17 16:52:29+00:00 (#9705)
item.description: Default one

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-17 16:52:19+00:00 (#9704)
item.description: def one?

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-05-17 16:51:40+00:00 (#9703)
item.description: MTRRs don’t cover the whole physical address space, there is a def one, right? The regions that are not described on MTRRs just default to MTRR def MSR.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-17 16:50:49+00:00 (#9702)
item.description: I mean, is it like that remapping causes to create something out of the range of MTRRs?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-17 16:50:14+00:00 (#9701)
item.description: Well, we build everything based on available MTRRs for the entire address space of MTRRs. Does the remapping change it at some point?

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-05-17 16:46:41+00:00 (#9700)
item.description: [discord] <unrustled.jimmies> Yep, i can try that now.

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-05-17 16:46:27+00:00 (#9699)
item.description: This is a bad advice for setting up your bios params, this is just for testing

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-05-17 16:45:57+00:00 (#9698)
item.description: Can you try setting up bios settings to "Use above 4g decode - no and/or remap 4g - no" just to test this theory?

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-05-17 16:44:57+00:00 (#9697)
item.description: @HughEverett do you build EPT pages for the whole physical address space? My random guess would be that those dirvers use MMIO which is remapped above the top of addressable dram memory and possible that area is not covered by your EPT

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-05-17 16:41:23+00:00 (#9696)
item.description: [discord] <unrustled.jimmies> Running env is baremetal windows 11

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-05-17 16:40:08+00:00 (#9695)
item.description:
[discord] <unrustled.jimmies> [reply]: It could be my drivers, i use Logi with default windows usb drivers since i saw `USBXHCI!Bulk_Stage_MapIntoRing+0x6df` in the stack trace, then installed Logi+ Native drivers then the stack trace changed to `igdkmdn64+0x4447e1` then i updated intel drivers then it changed to `nvlddmkm+0xd710a3` kicking off the EPT violation. Unfortunately im on the latest nvidia drivers so.
Not sure why its kicking off ept violations since i didnt set anything up, i just did `.connect local` and `load vmm` and thats when it BSOD's. Computer is new as well.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-17 16:39:54+00:00 (#9694)
item.description: I don't understand the logic behind this code. Adding _lock to a variable name doesn't have to do anything with locking it from modification by another core.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-17 16:34:06+00:00 (#9693)
item.description: It seems that it's because of an unexpected EPT violation. But why EPT violation? Did you run any command like !monitor or !epthook?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-17 16:33:00+00:00 (#9692)
item.description: What is the running environment? Is it a baremetal machine or VMware workstation?

item.title: @xatat26 on 2025-05-17 05:47:49+00:00 (#9690)
item.description: Hi regarding spinlock_lock() functionality: Even though I locked global variable on core 2 using spinlock_lock() , core 3 was able to print its value without it being unlocked using spinlock_unlock(). Why?

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-05-17 05:15:29+00:00 (#9689)
@HyperDbgBot on 2025-05-17 05:11:25+00:00 (#9687)
item.description:
[discord] <unrustled.jimmies> Got the stack trace by opening up the minidump in windbg
``` ffffc181`e70a55e8 fffff803`e9e73a3d : 00000000`000001aa ffffae8f`989aee60 00000000`00000003 ffffc181`e70a58d0 : nt!KeBugCheckEx ffffc181`e70a55f0 fffff803`e9c98e83 : 00000000`00000000 ffffae8f`989aecd0 00000000`00000000 00000000`00000001 : nt!RtlpGetStackLimitsEx+0x5d ffffc181`e70a5640 fffff803`e9ddd501 : ffffae8f`989aeaf0 ffffc181`e70a5dd0 ffffae8f`989aeaf0 fffff780`00000708 : nt!RtlDispatchException+0xe3 ffffc181`e70a58a0 fffff803`ea0a52b2 : cccccccc`ccccffff 6c894808`245c8948 57182474`89481024 57415641`55415441 : nt!KiDispatchException+0xac1 ffffc181`e70a5fb0 fffff803`ea0a5280 : fffff803`ea0b913e 00000000`00000000 00000000`00000000 00000000`00000000 : nt!KxExceptionDispatchOnExceptionStack+0x12 ffffae8f`989aeae8 fffff803`ea0b913e : 00000000`00000000 00000000`00000000 00000000`00000000 00000000`00000000 : nt!KiExceptionDispatchOnExceptionStackContinue ffffae8f`989aeaf0 fffff803`ea0b139b : ffffae8f`98836000 00000000`00000003 ffffae8f`989aee88 fffff803`a5d71607 : nt!KiExceptionDispatch+0x13e ffffae8f`989aecd0 fffff803`a4470343 : ffffae8f`00000003 00000000`00000d01 00000080`00203001 00000000`00000001 : nt!KiBreakpointTrap+0x35b ```

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-05-17 04:07:07+00:00 (#9686)
item.description: [discord] <unrustled.jimmies> I disable hyperv/hvci, boot using efiguard, disable dse and then load hyperdbg but i get exception on invalid stack. Anything im missing (will look into the logs later but just wanted to check if anyone has any ideas of what i could be doing dumb or if there are any logs generated i can look at)

item.title: @anna_junet on 2025-05-14 06:25:46+00:00 (#9683)
item.description: got it.thank your very much

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-14 05:52:34+00:00 (#9682)
item.description:
The equivalent to attaching to a process in the debugger mode is the '.process' or the '.thread' command:
https://docs.hyperdbg.org/commands/meta-commands/.process

item.title: @anna_junet on 2025-05-14 01:48:03+00:00 (#9680)
item.description: I got this error when i use debugger model.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-13 10:36:26+00:00 (#9679)
item.description:
You need to follow steps mentioned in this page:
https://docs.hyperdbg.org/getting-started/build-and-install
If you prefer to see these steps in a video, you should check:
https://youtu.be/MDZ9zYfqo50
And here for attaching to HyperDbg over the Debugger Mode: https://docs.hyperdbg.org/getting-started/attach-to-hyperdbg/debug

item.title: @anna_junet on 2025-05-13 10:30:43+00:00 (#9678)
item.description: My application run in windows10. How to switching to Debugger mode?

item.title: @anna_junet on 2025-05-13 10:29:57+00:00 (#9677)
item.description: thank your for your reply. How to operate it?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-13 10:26:08+00:00 (#9676)
item.description: The support for attaching in the VMI mode is not stable yet. You should use HyperDbg in the Debugger mode for switching into processes.

item.title: @anna_junet on 2025-05-13 10:23:45+00:00 (#9675)
item.description: hi everyone, how to build the hyperdbg-cli support --debugger args. I want to attach a process in VMI Mode.

item.title: @t0r0_ru on 2025-05-12 19:19:36+00:00 (#9673)
item.description: I’m sorry. The debugger seems to work. In the bundle the host computer - VmWare.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-08 06:38:32+00:00 (#9672)
item.description: For example, if you have a PCIe card to serial, it doesn't work with HyperDbg because the interface of communication is over PCIe BARs or custom PCIe IO ports which HyperDbg is not aware of.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-08 06:36:38+00:00 (#9671)
item.description: HyperDbg communicates with IO ports for serial debugging. I'm not sure if the interface of these serial emulators are the same.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-08 06:35:17+00:00 (#9670)
item.description: Yes. I told you earlier, the '.start' command only works in Debugger mode (not in VMI mode).

item.title: @t0r0_ru on 2025-05-08 06:27:51+00:00 (#9669)
item.description: HyperDbg "sees" these ports, but works exactly the same. That is, it does not work :)

item.title: @t0r0_ru on 2025-05-08 06:20:15+00:00 (#9668)
item.description: By the way, both VMware virtual machines communicate perfectly via Serial ports, thanks to this program.

item.title: @t0r0_ru on 2025-05-08 06:17:15+00:00 (#9667)
item.description: I tried the emulator https://www.serial-over-ethernet.com/downloads. This emulator can create a virtual port. Without success...

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-07 13:37:54+00:00 (#9666)
item.description: @t0r0_ru Did you find an alternative?

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-07 11:48:36+00:00 (#9665)
item.description: @HughEverett I use vmi mode on my local machine, and it can't even use the startup command.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-06 22:37:23+00:00 (#9663)
item.description: Other than that, everything is the same (e.g. you can scripts and trigger custom scripts in case of events) in the VMI Mode.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-06 22:36:15+00:00 (#9662)
item.description: VMI Mode contains all the features of the Debugger mode except you cannot put breakpoints, break to debugger in case of triggering an event, and step through the instructions. All of these capabilities are available in the Debugger Mode (not local VMI mode).

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-06 22:34:40+00:00 (#9661)
item.description: If you want to use HyperDbg in a full-featured mode, you need to run it in the Debugger Mode.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-06 22:33:43+00:00 (#9660)
item.description: Because I see sometimes VMWare doesn't properly handle serial connections over two VMs. But, Guest to host is perfectly fine.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-06 22:33:00+00:00 (#9659)
item.description: This might be bug with HyperDbg. Did you also have the same problem with running it from host?

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 11:25:12+00:00 (#9658)
item.description: OK

item.title: @t0r0_ru on 2025-05-06 11:25:03+00:00 (#9657)
item.description: If you succeed, please tell me how you did it.

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 11:25:03+00:00 (#9656)
item.description: I will try to compile the code again,

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 11:24:54+00:00 (#9655)
item.description: I think it should work if it is in a virtual machine.

item.title: @t0r0_ru on 2025-05-06 11:23:51+00:00 (#9654)
item.description: Although I read the documentation and watched the video and did everything as it is written and shown there. Maybe you can do it...

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 11:23:11+00:00 (#9652)
item.description: It has so many problems. So what is its meaning?

item.title: @t0r0_ru on 2025-05-06 11:22:38+00:00 (#9651)
item.description: It just freezes and that's it.

item.title: @t0r0_ru on 2025-05-06 11:22:02+00:00 (#9650)
item.description: Moreover - I tried to connect two VMWare. The server "sees" the client, but after connection the server does not respond to keystrokes.

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 11:14:57+00:00 (#9648)
item.description: Is that right? It doesn't support local mode?

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 11:14:29+00:00 (#9647)
item.description: But you said it doesn't support local mode?

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 11:14:10+00:00 (#9646)
item.description: I want to make it my own epthook.

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 11:13:38+00:00 (#9645)
item.description: So that means it doesn't work?

item.title: @t0r0_ru on 2025-05-06 11:13:12+00:00 (#9644)
item.description: After running the debugger you will get a BSOD. The current version of the debugger simply does not work in local mode at all.....

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 11:13:08+00:00 (#9643)
item.description: Yes, I'm doing it, thank you.

item.title: @t0r0_ru on 2025-05-06 11:11:21+00:00 (#9642)
item.description: But anyway it's useless...

item.title: @t0r0_ru on 2025-05-06 11:10:53+00:00 (#9641)
item.description: Before compilation you must change /** * @brief Activates the user-mode debugger */ #define ActivateUserModeDebugger FALSE on #define ActivateUserModeDebugger TRUE

item.title: @t0r0_ru on 2025-05-06 11:09:35+00:00 (#9640)
item.description: You must compile the sources in Visual Studio 2022.

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 11:00:54+00:00 (#9639)
item.description: I don't understand, what are the special instructions?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-06 07:42:36+00:00 (#9636)
item.description:
You need to see open security training course on HyperDbg. Plenty of examples for starting the process are there:
https://ost2.fyi/Dbg3301
Or in YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RDlp0PCFgxI&list=PLUFkSN0XLZ-kF1f143wlw8ujlH2A45nZY

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-06 07:40:37+00:00 (#9635)
item.description: HyperDbg doesn't use DEBUG FLAGs to start a process (to further enhance its transparency) instead it uses hypervisor tricks to intercept the execution of the first instruction. That's why it's not that easy to implement the similar approach in the VMI mode. Right now, it fully support process creation in the debugger mode.

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 07:36:12+00:00 (#9634)
item.description: Or did I not enter the correct instructions? Do you have any examples?

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 07:35:19+00:00 (#9633)
item.description: No matter what command I type, it always appears this prompt.

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 07:35:07+00:00 (#9632)
item.description: Vmi mode can't even start a process?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-06 07:30:44+00:00 (#9631)
item.description: If you want to debug a process (step through its instructions or start it from entry point or put breakpoints), you need to use HyperDbg in the debugger mode, not VMI mode.

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 07:24:09+00:00 (#9630)
item.description: I can't use the local computer.

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 07:16:45+00:00 (#9629)
item.description: Do you know why?

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 07:16:40+00:00 (#9628)
item.description: @HughEverett

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 06:23:41+00:00 (#9627)
item.description: Doesn't it support using ivm mode in local machine?

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 06:01:34+00:00 (#9626)
item.description: this why？

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 06:01:28+00:00 (#9625)
item.description: the user-mode debugger in VMI Mode is still in the beta version and not stable. we decided to exclude it from this release and release it in future versions. if you want to test the user-mode debugger in VMI Mode, you should build HyperDbg with special instructions. But starting processes is fully supported in the Debugger Mode. (it's not recommended to use it in VMI Mode yet!)

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-05-06 06:01:04+00:00 (#9624)
item.description: the user-mode debugger in VMI Mode is still in the beta version and not stable. we decided to exclude it from this release and release it in future versions. if you want to test the user-mode debugger in VMI Mode, you should build HyperDbg with special instructions. But starting processes is fully supported in the Debugger Mode. (it's not recommended to use it in VMI Mode yet!)

item.title: @t0int on 2025-05-05 11:53:26+00:00 (#9622)
item.description: Thanks!

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-05-05 11:52:55+00:00 (#9620)
item.description: https://t.me/HyperDbg

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-05-05 10:49:44+00:00 (#9619)
item.description: [discord] <t0int> Where can i join the telegram group

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-04-30 21:07:23+00:00 (#9615)
item.description: Yes

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-04-30 21:07:06+00:00 (#9614)
item.description: HyperDbg is highly privileged (hypervisor level), so it means you have control over the user mode applications and the OS kernel. Changing a register or a memory without knowing the consequences will definitely BSOD the guest kernel. You should know what you are trying to do.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-04-30 21:04:39+00:00 (#9613)
item.description: If you're breaking the guest (doing something wrong that guest crashes), the kernel of the guest will BSOD the system and obviously HyperDbg couldn't pause (CTRL+C) the guest again.
